The user is on macOS (they said "amcos" which I assume means "macOS") and wants me to find and remove all remnants of the Postman app using Spotlight or other means.

This is a good task for a todo list since it involves:
1. Finding all Postman-related files and directories
2. Removing them systematically

Let me create a todo list and then search for Postman files across common macOS locations.

Common locations for macOS app remnants:
- /Applications/ (main app)
- ~/Library/Application Support/
- ~/Library/Preferences/
- ~/Library/Caches/
- ~/Library/Logs/
- ~/Library/Saved Application State/
- ~/Library/Containers/
- ~/Library/Group Containers/
- /Library/Application Support/
- /Library/Preferences/
- /Library/Caches/

I should use Glob or Bash to search for these files, then remove them.

message.content: thx. in general is it possible to change a name of   a repo at github

content.thinking: The user is asking a general question about whether it's possible to rename a GitHub repository. This is a straightforward informational question that doesn't require any tools or task tracking. I should just provide a concise, helpful answer.

content.text:
Yes, you can rename a GitHub repository. Here's how:

**Steps:**
1. Go to your repo on GitHub
2. Click **Settings** tab
3. Scroll to **Repository name** field
4. Enter new name
5. Click **Rename**

**Important notes:**
- GitHub automatically redirects traffic from old name to new name
- You'll need to update your local clone's remote URL:
  ```bash
  git remote set-url origin https://github.com/username/new-repo-name.git
  ```
- Any existing links to the old name will redirect, but it's best to update:
  - Clone URLs in documentation
  - Webhooks
  - GitHub Actions secrets/variables referencing the repo
  - Any hardcoded references in CI/CD pipelines

**Caution:**
- If someone creates a new repo with your old name, the redirect stops working
- Forks keep their original name (they don't auto-rename)

The process is simple and GitHub handles it pretty gracefully with redirects.

message.content: i have a win10 computer nd eagerly awaiting microsoft 'extended service'. any news about that? support will end october 14

content.thinking:
The user is asking about Windows 10 extended support and mentions that support will end October 14. They want to know if there's news about Microsoft's extended service.

Let me search for current information about Windows 10 extended support, as this is a factual question about Microsoft's support plans that may have recent updates beyond my knowledge cutoff of January 2025.

The user mentions "October 14" - Windows 10's end of support is scheduled for October 14, 2025. Since the current date in the environment is 2025-10-10, that's just 4 days away! So this is very timely.

I should search for information about Windows 10 Extended Security Updates (ESU) program.

input.query: Windows 10 Extended Security Updates ESU 2025 program

I've found comprehensive information about the Windows 10 Extended Security Updates (ESU) program for 2025. Here's a summary:

## Overview

Windows 10 support ends on October 14, 2025, and individuals or organizations who elect to continue using Windows 10 after support ends will have the option of enrolling their PCs into a paid ESU subscription.(no content)The ESU program enables PCs to continue to receive critical and important security updates through an annual subscription service after support ends.

## Consumer ESU Program

The Extended Security Updates (ESU) program for Windows 10 provides customers with a more secure option to continue using their Windows 10 PCs after October 14, 2025, while they transition to Windows 11.(no content)ESU coverage for personal devices runs from Oct. 15, 2025, through Oct. 13, 2026.

**Enrollment options** include:
- Free enrollment if you're backing up files to OneDrive, regardless of whether you have a Microsoft 365 subscription
- Redeeming 1,000 Microsoft Rewards points
- One-time purchase option

**Important note for EEA users:** Microsoft has confirmed that it is making access to Windows 10's extended support updates (ESU) program completely free for an additional year, until October 14, 2026, for regions in the European Economic Area (EEA.)

## Commercial ESU Program

Extended Security Updates for organizations and businesses on Windows 10 can be purchased today through the Microsoft Volume Licensing Program, at $61 USD per device for Year One.(no content)The price doubles every consecutive year, for a maximum of three years.(no content)Year One starts in November 2025.(no content)The first ESU update which requires the activation will be the November 2025 security update.

## Requirements

To be eligible to install updates from the ESU program, devices must be running Windows 10, version 22H2.

content.thinking:
Great! I found detailed information about the Windows 10 ESU program. Let me summarize the key points for the user:

1. Support ends October 14, 2025 (just 4 days from now based on the system date)
2. ESU program IS available for consumers (not just enterprises)
3. There are FREE options available:
   - Free if backing up to OneDrive
   - Can use 1,000 Microsoft Rewards points
   - Or a one-time purchase option
4. ESU runs from October 15, 2025 to October 13, 2026 (one year)
5. Special note: EEA users get it completely free
6. Must be running Windows 10 version 22H2

This is good news for the user!

content.text:
Good news! The **Windows 10 Extended Security Updates (ESU)** program is confirmed and rolling out now. Here's what you need to know with just 4 days until support ends:

**For Consumers (Home users):**
- **Coverage:** Oct 15, 2025 - Oct 13, 2026 (1 year)
- **FREE options:**
  - Back up files to OneDrive (no Microsoft 365 subscription needed)
  - Redeem 1,000 Microsoft Rewards points
  - Or pay a one-time fee (price not specified)

**Special bonus:** If you're in the **EEA (European Economic Area), it's completely FREE** until Oct 14, 2026!

**Requirements:**
- Must be running **Windows 10 version 22H2**

**For Business:**
- $61 USD per device for Year 1 (Nov 2025)
- Doubles each year, max 3 years

**How to check your version:**
```
Settings > System > About
```

The ESU program should be available through Windows Update settings. Microsoft says it'll be fully available for all users by October 14, 2025.

So yes, you can keep your Windows 10 machine secure for at least another year without upgrading to Windows 11!
